Cholestasis is a feature of many chronic human liver diseases like primary biliary cirrhosis (1Rust C. Beuers U. Clin. Rev. Allergy Immunol... 2005; 28: 135-145Google Scholar). Hepatocyte damage by toxic bile acids is assumed to represent a key event for progression of cholestatic liver diseases (2Hofmann A.F. Liver.. 2002; 22: 14-19Google Scholar). Toxic bile acids induce hepatocellular apoptosis, thereby providing a cellular mechanism for bile acid-mediated liver injury and fibrogenesis (3Yoon J.H. Gores G.J. J. Hepatol... 2002; 37: 400-410Google Scholar, 4Rodrigues C.M. Fan G. Ma X. Kren B.T. Steer C.J. J. Clin. Investig... 1998; 101: 2790-2799Google Scholar, 5Reinehr R. Graf D. Haussinger D. Gastroenterology.. 2003; 125: 839-853Google Scholar, 6Canbay A. Higuchi H. Bronk S.F. Taniai M. Sebo T.J. Gores G.J. Gastroenterology.. 2002; 123: 1323-1330Google Scholar). The glycine and taurine conjugates of chenodeoxycholic acid (GCDCA, TCDCA) 2The abbreviations used are: GCDCA, glycochenodeoxycholic acid; TCDCA, taurochenodeoxycholic acid; FADD, Fas-associating protein with death domain; m.o.i., multiplicity of infection; Ntcp, sodium taurocholate cotransporting polypeptide; Z, benzyloxycarbonyl; fmk, fluoromethyl ketone; siRNA, small interfering RNA; TNFα, tumor necrosis factor α; DAPI, 4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole; dn, dominant negative.2The abbreviations used are: GCDCA, glycochenodeoxycholic acid; TCDCA, taurochenodeoxycholic acid; FADD, Fas-associating protein with death domain; m.o.i., multiplicity of infection; Ntcp, sodium taurocholate cotransporting polypeptide; Z, benzyloxycarbonyl; fmk, fluoromethyl ketone; siRNA, small interfering RNA; TNFα, tumor necrosis factor α; DAPI, 4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole; dn, dominant negative. are the predominant dihydroxy bile acids in cholestatic patients and have been held responsible for cholestasis-associated liver injury (7Schmucker D.L. Ohta M. Kanai S. Sato Y. Kitani K. Hepatology.. 1990; 12: 1216-1221Google Scholar). GCDCA is thought to induce hepatocyte apoptosis by Fas death receptor-dependent signaling that is independent of Fas ligand (8Faubion W. Guicciardi M. Miyoshi H. Bronk S. Roberts P. Svingen P. Kaufmann S. Gores G. J. Clin. Investig... 1999; 103: 137-145Google Scholar). In a recently proposed model, activation of NADPH oxidase isoforms by GCDCA is followed by generation of reactive oxygen species, which results in epidermal growth factor receptor-dependent tyrosine phosphorylation of Fas (5Reinehr R. Graf D. Haussinger D. Gastroenterology.. 2003; 125: 839-853Google Scholar, 9Reinehr R. Becker S. Keitel V. Eberle A. Grether-Beck S. Haussinger D. Gastroenterology.. 2005; 129: 2009-2031Google Scholar). GCDCA-induced oligomerization of Fas then causes activation of the initiator caspase-8, which requires the adaptor protein FADD. In hepatocytes, caspase-8 then would cause apoptosis via the mitochondrial pathway (10Barnhart B.C. Alappat E.C. Peter M.E. Semin Immunol... 2003; 15: 185-193Google Scholar). In cell-free systems, however, toxic bile acids like GCDCA can directly cause mitochondrial damage leading to cytochrome c leakage, which is followed by the activation of caspase-9 via the apoptosome (11Sola S. Brito M.A. Brites D. Moura J.J. Rodrigues C.M. Clin. Sci. (Lond.).. 2002; 103: 475-485Google Scholar). GCDCA can dose-dependently induce the mitochondrial permeability transition in isolated human mitochondria (12Sokol R.J. Dahl R. Devereaux M.W. Yerushalmi B. Kobak G.E. Gumpricht E. J. Pediatr. Gastroenterol. Nutr... 2005; 41: 235-243Google Scholar). In addition, a marked increase in reactive oxygen species production was observed within minutes in the mitochondria treated with GCDCA (12Sokol R.J. Dahl R. Devereaux M.W. Yerushalmi B. Kobak G.E. Gumpricht E. J. Pediatr. Gastroenterol. Nutr... 2005; 41: 235-243Google Scholar). Procaspase-8 appears to be processed late in Fas-dependent hepatocyte apoptosis, suggesting that only a small amount of procaspase-8 may actually be activated at the Fas receptor (13Bajt M.L. Lawson J.A. Vonderfecht S.L. Gujral J.S. Jaeschke H. Toxicol. Sci... 2000; 58: 109-117Google Scholar). Although caspase-6 is generally believed to be an effector caspase (14Cohen G.M. Biochem. J... 1997; 326: 1-16Google Scholar), it has recently been shown in Jurkat cell extracts to efficiently cleave caspase-8 and induce Bid-dependent cytochrome c release (15Cowling V. Downward J. Cell Death Differ.. 2002; 9: 1046-1056Google Scholar). The role of caspase-6 in bile acid-induced liver cell apoptosis remains unclear. The aims of our study were, therefore, to investigate the role of caspase-6 as well as the death receptor Fas in human liver cell lines for the induction of apoptosis by the major human hydrophobic bile acid GCDCA. Materials—The caspase inhibitors Z-VEID-fmk, Z-LEHD-fmk, and Z-IETD-fmk were from BD Pharmingen (San Diego, CA), Z-VAD-fmk was from Promega (Madison, WI). Primary antibodies against full-length and cleaved caspases-3, -6, -7, and -9 as well as Bid were purchased from Cell Signaling (Beverly, MA). Primary antibodies against caspase-8 were a generous gift from Dr. Peter Krammer (Division of Immunogenetics, German Cancer Research Centre, Heidelberg, Germany). Primary antibodies against the sodium taurocholate cotransporting polypeptide (Ntcp) were a generous gift of Dr. Bruno Stieger (University of Zurich, Switzerland). Primary antibodies against Fas and cytochrome were from BD Biosciences. Antibodies against β-actin as well as GCDCA, taurolithocholic acid, dimethyl sulfoxide, etoposide, and all other reagents were obtained from Sigma. Cell Culture and Stable Transfection of HepG2, Hep3B, and HuH7 Cells—HepG2, Hep3B, and HuH7 cells were grown at 37 °C under 5% CO2 in minimal essential medium (pH 7.4) containing 10% fetal bovine serum, 1% nonessential amino acids, 2 mmol/liter l-glutamine, 1 mmol/liter sodium pyruvate, 100 units/ml penicillin, 100 μg/ml streptomycin, and 0.25 μg/ml amphotericin B (complete culture medium). For transfection with rat Ntcp, HepG2 cells were seeded into 24-well tissue culture plates. After reaching ∼80% confluence, cells were transfected using a pcDNA3.1/Ntcp construct (16Glasova H. Berghaus T.M. Kullak-Ublick G.A. Paumgartner G. Beuers U. Eur. J. Clin. Investig... 2002; 32: 437-442Google Scholar). Complete culture medium was replaced by 2 ml of serum-free medium, containing 2 μg of the respective plasmid cDNA and 5 μl of FuGENE (Roche) in each well. After 4 h (37 °C; 5% CO2), 200 μl of fetal bovine serum were added to each well. Cells were incubated for 24 h (37 °C; 5% CO2) and subsequently harvested. Continuous selection was achieved by growth in culture medium supplemented with 1000 μg/ml (HepG2) or 500 μg/ml (Hep3B, HuH7) active geneticin. Preparation of Primary Rat Hepatocytes—Livers of narcotized male Sprague-Dawley rats were perfused 10 min with carbogen (95% O2, 5%CO2) equilibrated buffer A (122 mmol/liter sodium chloride, 5 mmol/liter potassium chloride, 0.4 mmol/liter potassium dihydrogen phosphate, 2 mmol/liter disodium hydrogen phosphate, 25 mmol/liter sodium bicarbonate, 0.5 mmol/liter EGTA) at 37 °C, then 5 min with buffer B (buffer A without EGTA, with 0.5 mmol/liter magnesium chloride, 0.4 mmol/liter magnesium sulfate, 3 mmol/liter calcium chloride, 0.225 g/liter collagenase IV) in a recirculating fashion. Tissue was minced with scissors and cells suspended by shaking in buffer B (without collagenase). Cells were filtered through 80-μm cheesecloth, centrifuged for 5 min at 50 × g at 4 °C, and suspended with buffer B. Cells were overlaid at 50% (v/v) isotonic and buffered Percoll™ (Amersham Biosciences) and then centrifuged at 50 × g for 5 min. The supernatant was removed and the pellet with living hepatocytes suspended in Leibovitz's L-15 medium (PAA Laboratories, Pasching, Austria) with 15 mmol/liter HEPES, 5% fetal calf serum, 0.1 μmol/liter insulin, 0.1 μmol/liter dexamethasone, 1% antibiotics and antimycotics (Invitrogen), and once again washed. Cells were counted and viability controlled by trypan blue stain. Cells were seeded in collagen-coated (5 μg/cm2) cell culture dishes with a density of 105 cells/cm2. Quantification of Apoptosis—Apoptosis was determined by assessing the characteristic nuclear changes of apoptosis using the DNA-binding dye 4,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole dihydrochloride and fluorescence microscopy. In addition, apoptosis was determined by measuring activation of the effector caspases-3 and -7. The activity assays were performed in subconfluent cells using commercially available caspase assay kits from Promega (ApoONE®) according to the recommendations of the manufacturer. Caspase-8 Assay—Caspase-8 activity was quantified in primary rat hepatocytes using a commercially available assay kit from Promega (Caspase-Glo 8 Assay®) according to the recommendations of the manufacturer. Primary rat hepatocytes were used after 24 h of culture and then stimulated with the respective bile acids for 4 h. Reverse Transcription-PCR—Total RNA was isolated from cultured HepG2, Huh7, and Hep3B cells using the Nucleo Spin RNA II kit (Machery-Nagel, Düren, Germany). Purified RNA was quantified by spectrophotometry and cDNA was prepared using the reverse transcriptase Superscript III (Invitrogen) as previously described in detail (17Bernt C. Vennegeerts T. Beuers U. Rust C. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun... 2006; 340: 800-806Google Scholar). 2 μg of the cDNA product was amplified by PCR with Taq DNA polymerase using standard protocols and the following primers for human Fas: sense 5′-AGA GTG TGT GCA CAA GGC TG-3′ and antisense 5′-CAC TCT GCA ACC TCT CTC CC-3′; glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, sense 5′-CGA GAG AAC TGA TTG ATA CCA T-3′ and antisense 5′-TGG CAT ACT ACC AGA TGA CC-3′. Products of PCR were analyzed with 2% agarose gels and ethidium bromide staining. siRNA-mediated Gene Silencing of Caspase-6, -8, and -9—siRNA targeted to the human caspase-6 (catalog number M-004406-02), caspase-8 (catalog number M-003466-05), caspase-3 (catalog number M-004307-02), and caspase-9 (catalog number M-003309-01) mRNA sequence as well as random oligonucleotide controls (catalog number D-001210-01) were purchased from Dharmacon (Lafayette, CO). HepG2-Ntcp cells at 30–40% confluency were transfected using Oligofectamine (Invitrogen) using 10–50 nmol/liter siRNA according to the manufacturer's instructions. Cells were used for experiments 24 to 48 h after transfection. Down-regulation of caspase-6, caspase-8, caspase-3, and caspase-9 was shown by immunoblot analysis. Immunoblot Analysis—Subconfluent cells were stimulated, washed with phosphate-buffered saline, homogenized in ice-cold lysis buffer (20 mmol/liter Tris-HCl, pH 8, 150 mmol/liter NaCl, 2 mmol/liter EDTA, 1% Triton, 100 μmol/liter vanadate, 10 mmol/liter NaF, 1 mmol/liter phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, Complete® by Roche), incubated for 5 min on ice, sonicated, and centrifuged for 5 min at 14,000 × g at 4 °C. The supernatant (50 μg of protein) was resolved by 12% SDS-PAGE, transferred to Immobilon-P membranes (Millipore, Eschborn, Germany), and probed against the appropriate primary antibody at a dilution of 1:1000 in 1% milk, TBS-T and 1% albumin overnight. Peroxidase-conjugated goat anti-rabbit IgG antibody (Santa Cruz Biotechnologies) was incubated at a dilution of 1:5000. Membranes were stripped and reprobed with antibodies against β-actin (1:3,500) or glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (1:100,000) to ensure equal loading. For cytochrome c immunoblots, cytosolic fractions were prepared by washing the cells twice with ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline, scraping them with 150 μl of homogenization buffer (20 mmol/liter Tris, pH 7,4, 250 mmol/liter saccharose, 2 mmol/liter EGTA, 1 mmol/liter phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 10 mmol/liter 2-mercaptoethanol, 50 μmol/liter leupeptin, and 25 μg of aprotinin) and homogenization by passing several times through a 26-gauge 5/8 inch needle. The homogenate was centrifuged for 8 min at 25 p.s.i. (A-110 rotor, Beckman Airfuge). The supernatant was recovered as the cytosolic fraction and normalized by protein content. For cytochrome c immunoblots 10 μg of protein were loaded onto 15% SDS-polyacrylamide gels. Adenoviral Infection—The recombinant replication-deficient adenovirus Ad5-dnFADD (a generous gift of Dr. H. Moshage, Center for Liver, Digestive and Metabolic Diseases, University Medical Center Groningen, Groningen), and Addl70-3 (a generous gift of Dr. Frank Graham, Department of Biology, McMaster University, Hamilton, Ontario, Canada), an empty adenovirus for control experiments (18Bett A.J. Haddara W. Prevec L. Graham F.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A... 1994; 91: 8802-8806Google Scholar), were grown and purified by banding twice in CsCl gradients as described previously (19Rust C. Karnitz L.M. Paya C.V. Moscat J. Simari R.D. Gores G.J. J. Biol. Chem... 2000; 275: 20210-20216Google Scholar). For adenovirus infection, HepG2-Ntcp cells were grown to 50–75% confluence. The medium was replaced with Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium containing 10% fetal calf serum, and Ad5-dnFADD or Addl70-3 viral stock solutions were added at a multiplicity of infection (m.o.i.) of 5. After 18 h, medium was removed and cells were split and then used for experiments 48 h later. Immunocytochemical AU1 Staining—To visualize expression of Ad5-dnFADD in infected cells, immunocytochemical staining for the AU1-tag of this adenoviral plasmid was performed after infection (m.o.i. 5) in HepG2-Ntcp cells seeded on uncoated glass coverslips in 12-well culture plates. Cells were washed with phosphate-buffered saline and then fixed using paraformaldehyde (3%, 20 min, 4 °C). Fixed cells were blocked for 1 h in phosphate-buffered saline containing 5% bovine serum albumin. Antibodies against AU1 (1:200) were diluted in 5% bovine serum albumin/TBS-T and applied for 24 h. After washing with TBS-T, Alexa Fluor 488 (fluorescein isothiocyanate)-coupled secondary antibodies (1:200 in TBS-T) and Hoechst 33342 (DAPI, 1:200) were applied for 1 h. Cells were visualized using an Axioskop (Zeiss, Germany). Statistics—Results from at least 3 independent experiments are expressed as mean ± S.D. Differences between groups were compared by analysis of variance for repeated measures and a post hoc Bonferroni test to compare for multiple comparisons. Activation of Caspase-6 Is Important for GCDCA-induced Apoptosis—The Fas-containing human hepatoma cell line HepG2 stably transfected with the bile acid transporter sodium taurocholate cotransporting polypeptide (Ntcp) (16Glasova H. Berghaus T.M. Kullak-Ublick G.A. Paumgartner G. Beuers U. Eur. J. Clin. Investig... 2002; 32: 437-442Google Scholar) was used to investigate the role of caspase-6 in GCDCA-induced apoptosis. We confirmed that these HepG2-Ntcp cells express Ntcp and effectively transport radiolabeled taurocholic acid (data not shown). GCDCA is known to effectively induce apoptosis in human hepatoma cells and primary rat hepatocytes in a concentration-dependent manner at low micromolar concentrations of 50–100 μmol/liter (5Reinehr R. Graf D. Haussinger D. Gastroenterology.. 2003; 125: 839-853Google Scholar, 20Rust C. Bauchmuller K. Bernt C. Vennegeerts T. Fickert P. Fuchsbichler A. Beuers U. Gut.. 2006; 55: 719-727Google Scholar). Based on these previous observations we used GCDCA at a concentration of 75 μmol/liter for the in vitro studies. We first tested whether GCDCA induces cleavage of caspase-6 in HepG2-Ntcp cells. Indeed, GCDCA (75 μmol/liter) induced caspase-6-cleavage that started 30 min after bile acid administration and reached a maximum after 2–3 h (Fig. 1A). Activation of caspase-6 preceded activation of the initiator caspase-8 in this experimental setting. We next transfected HepG2-Ntcp cells with specific siRNA against caspase-6 to scrutinize the role of caspase-6 in bile acid-induced apoptosis. Full-length caspase-6 was almost completely down-regulated 24 h after transfection with siRNA against caspase-6 at a concentration of 50 nmol/liter, whereas no reduction was observed in scrambled siRNA-transfected cells (Fig. 1B). We next analyzed if bile acid-induced apoptosis is reduced in caspase-6 siRNA-transfected HepG2-Ntcp cells. In cells transfected with siRNA against caspase-6 for 24 h, GCDCA-induced apoptosis was markedly reduced as determined by morphological assessment of apoptosis by DAPI staining (Fig. 2A) and caspase-3/-7 measurement (Fig. 2B). Because quantification of apoptosis by DAPI staining and by a caspase-3/-7 assay led to similar results, the latter was used for the remainder of the experiments. Although GCDCA-induced apoptosis was reduced by 50%, apoptosis induced by TNFα (50 ng/ml) in combination with actinomycin D (0.2 μg/ml) or etoposide (30 μmol/liter) was unchanged in caspase-6 siRNA-transfected cells, suggesting that caspase-6 is important for bile acid-induced apoptosis, but not for apoptosis induced by other stimuli (Fig. 2B). Comparable results were obtained with 20 μmol/liter taurolithocholic acid, another proapoptotic bile acid (data not shown). GCDCA-induced Caspase-6 Cleavage Is Downstream of Caspase-9 and -3 and Upstream of Caspase-8—In untransfected and scrambled siRNA-transfected cells, GCDCA (75 μmol/liter) activated caspases-3, -6, -7, -8, and -9 after 4 h as shown by immunoblot analysis with antibodies against cleaved caspases (Fig. 3A). In caspase-6 siRNA-transfected cells, cleaved caspase-6 was, as expected, not detectable and cleaved caspases-3 and -7 were reduced after stimulation with GCDCA (Fig. 3A), confirming the results of the caspase-3/-7 activity assays. In addition, initiator caspase-9 and caspase-8 were also reduced in caspase-6 siRNA-transfected cells, suggesting that caspase-6 might by part of a feedback loop in GCDCA-induced apoptosis (Fig. 3A). Activation of caspases-3, -6, and -7 was also dose-dependently reduced in GCDCA-stimulated HepG2-Ntcp cells using increasing concentrations of the caspase-6 inhibitor Z-VEID-fmk and reached control levels at a concentration of 20 μmol/liter (Fig. 3B). Likewise, GCDCA-induced apoptosis was significantly reduced using 20 μmol/liter Z-VEID-fmk as determined by a caspase-3/-7 assay (data not shown). Although cleaved caspase-8 was reduced to control levels using 10 μmol/liter of Z-VEID-fmk in GCDCA-stimulated cells, cleaved caspase-9 was detectable even at the highest Z-VEID-fmk concentration in the same experimental setting (Fig. 3B). It has to be noted, however, that the specificity of these caspase inhibitors has been questioned in a recent study (21McStay G.P. Salvesen G.S. Green D.R. Cell Death Differ.. 2008; 15: 322-331Google Scholar) and should therefore be interpreted with caution. We next used primary rat hepatocytes to test if these results are reproducible in non-malignant hepatocytes. GCDCA at 75 μmol/liter induced cytochrome c release and hepatocyte apoptosis in primary rat hepatocytes that was also significantly reduced using the caspase-6 inhibitor Z-VEID-fmk as assessed by morphological (not shown) and biochemical criteria (Fig. 4A) of apoptosis. In this experimental setting, inhibition of caspase-6 also reduced GCDCA-induced caspase-8 activity to control levels (Fig. 4B) and inhibited caspase-3 activation (Fig. 4C). Because the true specificity of caspase inhibitors is unclear (21McStay G.P. Salvesen G.S. Green D.R. Cell Death Differ.. 2008; 15: 322-331Google Scholar), these data again have to be interpreted with caution. However, a siRNA approach is not technically feasible in primary hepatocytes. We next used caspase-9 siRNA-transfected HepG2-Ntcp cells to determine whether caspase-6 activation is caspase-9-dependent. Full-length caspase-9 was down-regulated to almost control levels 24 h after transfection with siRNA against caspase-9 at a concentration of 50 nmol/liter (Fig. 5A). Apoptosis was reduced by 60% in these caspase-9 siRNA-transfected cells (Fig. 5B). GCDCA-induced activation of caspase-6 was markedly down-regulated in caspase-9 siRNA-transfected cells (Fig. 5A). Similar results were obtained using the caspase-9 inhibitor Z-LEHD-fmk (5–20 μmol/liter), which dose-dependently reduced cleavage of caspase-9 as well as caspase-6, whereas full-length capase-9 levels remained unchanged (data not shown). We repeated these experiments with caspase-3 siRNA-transfected cells to determine next, if activation of caspase-6 is also caspase-3-dependent. Caspase-6 activation was reduced in caspase-3 siRNA-transfected cells treated with GCDCA (75 μmol/liter) for 2 h (Fig. 5C). Apoptosis was markedly reduced in these caspase-3-deficient cells as determined by morphology (Fig. 5D) and caspase-3/-7 activation (not shown). Collectively, these results demonstrate that caspase-6 is activated in bile acid-induced apoptosis. GCDCA-induced activation of caspase-6 appears to be downstream of caspase-9 and caspase-3 as well as upstream of caspase-8, suggesting that caspase-6 might be part of a feedback loop in bile acid-induced apoptosis (Fig. 9). This effect is bile acid-specific, because apoptosis induced by other well defined stimuli was unchanged in caspase-6-deficient cells. GCDCA Effectively Induces Hepatocyte Apoptosis in the Absence of Fas—It has been suggested that bile acids can induce hepatocyte apoptosis by both Fas death receptor-dependent and death receptor-independent signaling (9Reinehr R. Becker S. Keitel V. Eberle A. Grether-Beck S. Haussinger D. Gastroenterology.. 2005; 129: 2009-2031Google Scholar, 12Sokol R.J. Dahl R. Devereaux M.W. Yerushalmi B. Kobak G.E. Gumpricht E. J. Pediatr. Gastroenterol. Nutr... 2005; 41: 235-243Google Scholar). To determine the role of the death receptor Fas in GCDCA-induced apoptosis we employed the Fas-deficient human hepatoma cell lines Hep3B and HuH7 (22Jiang S. Song M.J. Shin E.C. Lee M.O. Kim S.J. Park J.H. Hepatology.. 1999; 29: 101-110Google Scholar, 23Higuchi H. Bronk S.F. Takikawa Y. Werneburg N. Takimoto R. El-Deiry W. Gores G.J. J. Biol. Chem... 2001; 276: 38610-38618Google Scholar). First, the absence of Fas was confirmed both on mRNA and protein levels. In contrast to HepG2, neither Fas-mRNA nor Fas-protein were detectable in Hep3B and HuH7 cells (Fig. 6, A and B). Because bile acid-mediated apoptosis requires transport of bile acids into cells (8Faubion W. Guicciardi M. Miyoshi H. Bronk S. Roberts P. Svingen P. Kaufmann S. Gores G. J. Clin. Investig... 1999; 103: 137-145Google Scholar), we then developed bile acid transporting cell lines. Both Hep3B and HuH7 hepatoma cell lines were stably transfected with the sodium-dependent bile acid transporter Ntcp. Expression of Ntcp was confirmed by immunoblot (Fig. 6, C and D) and efficient sodium-dependent bile acid uptake was confirmed by performing uptake studies with radiolabeled taurocholate (data not shown). GCDCA (75 μmol/liter) induced apoptosis in Hep3B-Ntcp and HuH7-Ntcp cells after 4 h as measured by caspase-3/-7 activity (Fig. 6, C and D). Taurolithocholic acid, another proapoptotic bile acid, also induced significant apoptosis in Hep3B-Ntcp cells (Fig. 6C) after 4 h. In both cell lines, GCDCA induced marked cytochrome c release as a marker of mitochondrial dysfunction in the Ntcp-transfected, but not in the parent cell lines (Fig. 6E). Likewise, GCDCA did not induce apoptosis in the parent non-bile salt transporting Hep3B and HuH7 cells (Fig. 6, C and D). Taken together, these results suggest that GCDCA can effectively induce hepatocyte apoptosis in the absence of Fas. GCDCA-induced Apoptosis Is Reduced in FADD-deficient Cells—To determine whether other death receptors in addition to Fas might be involved in GCDCA-induced apoptosis, we next inhibited FADD, because all major death receptors require the FADD adaptor protein for transmitting their apoptotic signal (24Tourneur L. Buzyn A. Chiocchia G. Med. Immunol... 2005; 4: 1Google Scholar). This was achieved by infection of HepG2-Ntcp cells with an adenoviral construct containing a dominant negative FADD (Ad5-dnFADD). At a m.o.i. of 5, HepG2-Ntcp cells were effectively infected with Ad5-dnFADD as demonstrated by immunocytochemical staining of the AU1-tag (Fig. 7A) as well as immunoblot analysis (Fig. 7B). Infection of HepG2-Ntcp cells with this Ad5-dnFADD construct reduced GCDCA-mediated apoptosis by 50% as demonstrated by caspase-3/-7 assays (Fig. 7C). However, when apoptosis was induced by TNFα in combination with actinomycin D, a well known death receptor stimulus that requires recruitment of FADD, caspase-3/-7 activity was reduced to almost control levels. Thus, GCDCA can induce hepatocyte apoptosis even in the absence of Fas as well as of other death receptors, probably by directly activating the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis as an escape mechanism. Role of Caspase-8 in GCDCA-induced Apoptosis—Caspase-8 is the first caspase to become activated in death receptor-mediated apoptosis. To study the role of caspase-8 in GCDCA-induced apoptosis we induced down-regulation of caspase-8 in HepG2-Ntcp cells using specific siRNA against caspase-8. Full-length caspase-8 was down-regulated to almost control levels 24 h after transfection with siRNA against caspase-8 at a concentration of 10 and 50 nmol/liter, whereas no reduction was observed in controls transfected with siRNA against green fluorescent protein (Fig. 8A). The lower siRNA concentration (10 nmol/liter) was used for the remainder of the experiments. We next analyzed if bile acid-induced apoptosis as determined by a caspase-3/-7 assay is reduced in caspase-8 siRNA-transfected HepG2-Ntcp cells. In cells transfected with siRNA against caspase-8 (10 nmol/liter), GCDCA-induced apoptosis was reduced by 26% (Fig. 8B). In contrast, caspase-3/7 activity was reduced by 79% when apoptosis was induced by TNFα in combination with actinomycin D, a well known death receptor stimulus that requires caspase-8 signaling. In untransfected and control siRNA-transfected cells, GCDCA (75 μmol/liter) activated caspases-3, -7, -8, and -9 after 4 h as shown by immunoblot analysis with antibodies against cleaved caspases (Fig. 8C). In caspase-8 siRNA-transfected cells, full-length and cleaved caspase-8 was markedly reduced, but cleaved caspases-3, -7, and -9 were nearly unchanged after stimulation with GCDCA (Fig. 8C). In contrast, cleaved caspases-3, -7, -8, and -9 were hardly detectable in caspase-8 siRNA-transfected cells, when apoptosis was induced with TNFα and actinomycin D, indicating that lower levels of activated caspase-8 are needed in GCDCA-induced apoptosis in contrast to true death receptor-induced apoptosis. GCDCA-induced cleavage of Bid as a functional read-out of caspase-8 inhibition was reduced in caspase-8 siRNA-transfected cells (Fig. 8D). Of note, activation of caspase-6 was also markedly reduced in caspase-8 siRNA-transfected cells treated with GCDCA (Fig. 8D). Collectively, these observations indicate that proapoptotic bile acids can still induce hepatocyte apoptosis, when the extrinsic death receptor pathways are blocked. The novel findings of the present study indicate that caspase-6 plays a critical role in bile acid-induced apoptosis of human liver cell lines and primary rat hepatocytes. In addition, this study suggests that major human hydrophobic bile acids like GCDCA are still able to induce hepatocyte apoptosis when death-receptor pathways are blocked. The role of caspase-6 in hepatocyte apoptosis has not been studied so far. Caspase-6 is generally considered to be a member of the executioner caspases in the caspase family of cell death proteases (14Cohen G.M. Biochem. J... 1997; 326: 1-16Google Scholar). Similar to the other known executioner caspases, caspase-3 and -7, caspase-6 has a short prodomain, but appears to play only a minor role in poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase cleavage (14Cohen G.M. Biochem. J... 1997; 326: 1-16Google Scholar, 25Lavrik I.N. Golks A. Krammer P.H. J. Clin. Investig... 2005; 115: 2665-2672Google Scholar). In Jurkat cells, caspase-6 has recently been identified as a protease that can directly cleave caspase-8 in cytochrome c-activated extracts (15Cowling V. Downward J. Cell Death Differ.. 2002; 9: 1046-1056Google Scholar). In addition, purified caspase-6 was sufficient to induce Bid-dependent cytochrome c releasing activity in Jurkat cell extracts, whereas inhibition of caspase-6 reduced caspase-8 activation (15Cowling V. Downward J. Cell Death Differ.. 2002; 9: 1046-1056Google Scholar). There is also evidence that caspase-6 is an initiator caspase in reservatrol-induced apoptosis in T cell leukemia cell lines (26Bernhard D. Tinhofer I. Tonko M. Hubl H. Ausserlechner M.J. Greil R. Kofler R. Csordas A. Cell Death Differ.. 2000; 7: 834-842Google Scholar). However, caspase-6 does not seem to play a major role in anticancer drug-induced apoptosis in cancer cell lines (27Loegering D.A. Ruchaud S. Earnshaw W.C. Kaufmann S.H. Cell Death Differ.. 2006; 13: 346-347Google Scholar). Apoptosis induced by the Fas antibody Jo-2 in C3Heb/FeJ mice was used to analyze the time course of caspase-8 activation (13Bajt M.L. Lawson J.A. Vonderfecht S.L. Gujral J.S. Jaeschke H. Toxicol. Sci... 2000; 58: 109-117Google Scholar). Interestingly, the majority of procaspase-8 was processed late in this experimental system, suggesting that only a small amount of procaspase-8 was actually activated at the Fas receptor, whereas most of caspase-8 activation supposedly occurred by one or more unidentified effector caspases after mitochondrial activation (13Bajt M.L. Lawson J.A. Vonderfecht S.L. Gujral J.S. Jaeschke H. Toxicol. Sci... 2000; 58: 109-117Google Scholar). In our study, caspase-6 was strongly activated in bile acid-induced apoptosis. Inhibition of caspase-6 in human hepatoma cells significantly inhibited GCDCA-induced caspase-8 cleavage and apoptosis, therefore establishing caspase-6 as a potential activator of caspase-8 and confirming that this pathway may have a critical role in promotion of bile acid-induced apoptosis. In contrast, apoptosis induced by treatment with TNFα in combination with actinomycin D or etoposide was unchanged in caspase-6-deficient human hepatoma cells. Activation of the effector caspases-3 and -7 was also markedly reduced in caspase-6-deficient cells. In addition, down-regulation of caspase-9 and caspase-3 by specific siRNA resulted in a distinct reduction of caspase-6 activation in GCDCA-induced apoptosis suggesting that these caspases are upstream of caspase-6 in our experimental system. Caspase-6 has also been placed downstream of caspase-3 in the past (28Slee E.A. Harte M.T. Kluck R.M. Wolf B.B. Casiano C.A. Newmeyer D.D. Wang H.G. Reed J.C. Nicholson D.W. Alnemri E.S. Green D.R. Martin S.J. J. Cell Biol... 1999; 144: 281-292Google Scholar). Taken together, caspase-6 appears to be part of a feedback loop in bile acid-induced apoptosis of hepatocytes thereby enhancing the toxicity of proapototic bile acids (Fig. 9). Further studies using in vivo models of liver injury should not only provide a more complete picture of the role of caspase-6 in bile acid-induced apoptosis, but also evaluate caspase-6 as a potential therapeutic target for reducing bile acid-induced hepatocellular damage. Because activation of caspase-6 appears to be of importance for bile acid-induced apoptosis, but not for apoptosis induced by other stimuli, targeting caspase-6 might offer a better approach to selectively reduce bile acid-induced apoptotic liver injury. In the second part of this study we could demonstrate that GCDCA at moderate micromolar concentrations effectively induces apoptosis in two Fas-deficient human hepatoma cell lines suggesting that bile acid-induced apoptosis still occurs in the absence of this death receptor. In the past, bile acids such as GCDCA have been shown to induce hepatocyte apoptosis by a Fas death receptor-dependent mechanism (8Faubion W. Guicciardi M. Miyoshi H. Bronk S. Roberts P. Svingen P. Kaufmann S. Gores G. J. Clin. Investig... 1999; 103: 137-145Google Scholar, 29Reinehr R. Becker S. Hongen A. Haussinger D. J. Biol. Chem... 2004; 279: 23977-23987Google Scholar). In primary rat hepatocytes, GCDCA has been shown to first activate NADPH oxidase isoforms followed by generation of reactive oxygen species resulting in epidermal growth factor receptor-dependent tyrosine phosphorylation of Fas (5Reinehr R. Graf D. Haussinger D. Gastroenterology.. 2003; 125: 839-853Google Scholar, 9Reinehr R. Becker S. Keitel V. Eberle A. Grether-Beck S. Haussinger D. Gastroenterology.. 2005; 129: 2009-2031Google Scholar). However, hepatocyte apoptosis was also observed in the lpr bile duct-ligated mouse, which only has minimal Fas expression (30Miyoshi H. Rust C. Roberts P.J. Burgart L.J. Gores G.J. Gastroenterology.. 1999; 117: 669-677Google Scholar). Although hepatocyte apoptosis was diminished in this model of extrahepatic cholestasis, the rate of apoptosis increased over time suggesting that Fas-independent mechanisms of apoptosis were also occurring in these animals. Bile acids have also been postulated to cause direct mitochondrial cytotoxicity thereby activating the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis (12Sokol R.J. Dahl R. Devereaux M.W. Yerushalmi B. Kobak G.E. Gumpricht E. J. Pediatr. Gastroenterol. Nutr... 2005; 41: 235-243Google Scholar, 31Sola S. Aranha M.M. Steer C.J. Rodrigues C.M. Curr. Issues Mol. Biol... 2007; 9: 123-138Google Scholar). Indeed, bile acids induced mitochondrial generation of reactive oxygen species, mitochondrial membrane potential depolarization, and the mitochondrial permeability transition in primary rat hepatocytes (32Rodrigues C.M. Ma X. Linehan-Stieers C. Fan G. Kren B.T. Steer C.J. Cell Death Differ.. 1999; 6: 842-854Google Scholar). Mitochondrial cytochrome c release is FADD/caspase-8-dependent during death receptor-mediated apoptosis of type II cells such as hepatocytes (33Scaffidi C. Fulda S. Srinivasan A. Friesen C. Li F. Tomaselli K.J. Debatin K.M. Krammer P.H. Peter M.E. EMBO J.. 1998; 17: 1675-1687Google Scholar). Thus, inhibition of FADD/caspase-8 signaling can help differentiate death receptor-associated versus direct mitochondrial dysfunction in type II. We therefore initially inhibited FADD using a dnFADD in an adenoviral vector to further establish the functional role of death receptors for bile acid-induced apoptosis in our model. Inhibition of FADD would not only block Fas-mediated, but also TRAIL-mediated apoptosis, which has also been shown to be involved in GCDCA-induced apoptosis (23Higuchi H. Bronk S.F. Takikawa Y. Werneburg N. Takimoto R. El-Deiry W. Gores G.J. J. Biol. Chem... 2001; 276: 38610-38618Google Scholar). Interestingly, GCDCA still induced apoptosis in dnFADD-infected human hepatoma cells, although it was reduced by 50%. In contrast, TNFα-induced death receptor apoptosis was inhibited to control levels in the same experimental system. GCDCA-induced apoptosis has also been demonstrated to occur in the absence of FADD in primary rat hepatocytes (34Schoemaker M.H. Gommans W.M. de la Rosa L.C. Homan M. Klok P. Trautwein C. van Goor H. Poelstra K. Haisma H.J. Jansen P.L. Moshage H. J. Hepatol... 2003; 39: 153-161Google Scholar), therefore excluding a potential influence of the malignant transformation in the HepG2 hepatoma cells employed in our model. These results suggest that proapoptotic human bile acids like GCDCA at moderate micromolar concentrations representative of those found in cholestatic human liver injury are still capable to induce hepatocyte apoptosis in human and rodent hepatocytes by the intrinsic pathway when death receptor activation is inhibited. Because the intrinsic and extrinsic pathways can act independently to initiate apoptosis, bile acids most likely primarily activate death receptors as documented by various studies. When this fast extrinsic pathway is not available, toxic bile acids can induce apoptosis in hepatocytes by activating the intrinsic pathway as an escape mechanism, whereas this does not occur in pure death receptor signaling as exemplified by TNFα/actinomycin D-induced apoptosis. Thus, inhibition of death receptor signaling alone is probably not sufficient to reduce hepatocyte apoptosis and consecutive liver damage induced by toxic bile acids in cholestatic liver diseases. We thank Dr. Gregory Gores for helpful discussion of the manuscript.

In human hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), epithelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT) correlates with aggressiveness of tumors and poor survival. We employed a model of EMT based on immortalized p19ARF null hepatocytes (MIM), which display tumor growth upon expression of oncogenic Ras and undergo EMT through the synergism of Ras and transforming growth factor (TGF)-β. Here, we show that the interleukin-related protein interleukin-like EMT inducer (ILEI), a novel EMT-, tumor- and metastasis-inducing protein, cooperates with oncogenic Ras to cause TGF-β-independent EMT. Ras-transformed MIM hepatocytes overexpressing ILEI showed cytoplasmic E-cadherin, loss of ZO-1 and induction of α-smooth muscle actin as well as platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)/PDGF-R isoforms. As shown by dominant-negative PDGF-R expression in these cells, ILEI-induced PDGF signaling was required for enhanced cell migration, nuclear accumulation of β-catenin, nuclear pY-Stat3 and accelerated growth of lung metastases. In MIM hepatocytes expressing the Ras mutant V12-C40, ILEI collaborated with PI3K signaling resulting in tumor formation without EMT. Clinically, human HCC samples showed granular or cytoplasmic localization of ILEI correlating with well and poorly differentiated tumors, respectively. In conclusion, these data indicate that ILEI requires cooperation with oncogenic Ras to govern hepatocellular EMT through mechanisms involving PDGF-R/β-catenin and PDGF-R/Stat3 signaling.

The biogenesis of photosynthetic complexes is assisted by a growing number of trans-acting factors in both chloroplasts and cyanobacteria. We have previously shown that the periplasmic PratA factor from Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 (Synechocystis 6803) is required for adequate C-terminal processing of the PsbA (D1) subunit of photosystem II (PSII) supporting the idea that the early steps of PSII assembly occur at the plasma membrane. Here we report on the molecular analysis of the interaction between PratA and the D1 protein. Both yeast two-hybrid and glutathione S-transferase pulldown assays revealed that PratA binds to the soluble forms of both mature and precursor D1 C-terminal regions. In agreement with that finding, the binding region was mapped to amino acid positions 314-328 of D1 by applying a peptide-scanning approach. Approximately 10-20% of the soluble PratA factor was found to be associated with membranes in a D1-dependent manner. Sucrose density gradient centrifugations allowed the identification of a specific membrane subfraction that contains both PratA and D1 and which might represent a transfer and/or connecting region between plasma and thylakoid membrane. Imaging data obtained with enhanced cyan fluorescent protein-labeled D1 protein in wild-type and pratA mutant backgrounds further supported this notion. Ossenbühl F. Sikorski M. Berry S. Eichacker L.A. Nickelsen J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 44639-44694Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). The analysis of pulse-labeled proteins had suggested that the C-terminal processing of the reaction-center protein D1 is affected by a pratA mutation. In agreement with this finding, a direct interaction between the soluble C-terminal 68 amino acids of the D1 precursor (pD1) and PratA was documented using a yeast two-hybrid system (14Klinkert B. Ossenbühl F. Sikorski M. Berry S. Eichacker L.A. Nickelsen J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 44639-44694Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar) (Fig. 1). To test whether PratA binding is specific for the precursor form of the D1 protein, we have now analyzed a version that lacks the C-terminal extension characteristic of the precursor using the same two-hybrid approach in yeast. As shown in Fig. 1A, PratA also recognizes the C-terminal segment of the mature D1 (mD1), suggesting that the 16-amino acid extension present in the precursor is not required for binding of PratA. Instead, the 52 amino acids retained in mD1 appear to contain the crucial determinants that mediate the D1-PratA interaction. Previous attempts to demonstrate this interaction using in vitro approaches yielded ambiguous results (14Klinkert B. Ossenbühl F. Sikorski M. Berry S. Eichacker L.A. Nickelsen J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 44639-44694Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). However, optimization of the conditions used for GST pulldown assays has now allowed us to confirm the specific interaction of the D1 protein and PratA also in vitro (Fig. 1B). Sepharose-bound GST alone failed to capture recombinant His-tagged PratA protein. In contrast, matrix-bound GST fused to the C-terminal portion of either the precursor or the mature D1 interacted with recombinant PratA, and PratA could subsequently be eluted from the matrix material under denaturing conditions (Fig. 1B). As a negative control, E. coli proteins from a strain containing no recombinant PratA protein were always analyzed in parallel. No signals were obtained in these cases. Taken together, the data thus strongly suggest that PratA specifically recognizes the C-terminal sequence that is common to pD1 and mD1. Recombinant PratA protein was incubated with the PepSpots™ membrane bearing the whole peptide set, and subsequent decoration with the αPratA antibody revealed that PratA specifically binds to peptide No. 8, corresponding to positions 314-328 of the D1 protein (Fig. 2, A and B). Peptide No. 1 (positions 293-307) was also recognized by PratA, although the signal was less pronounced. We then analyzed mutant versions of the D1 C terminus that lacked either peptide 1 or 8 in the yeast two-hybrid system. Deletion of amino acids 293-307 had only a limited impact on yeast growth, suggesting that these positions make only a minor contribution, if any, to PratA-D1 complex formation (Fig. 2C). In contrast, when residues 314-328 were deleted, no interaction between PratA and the D1 segment was observed (Fig. 2C). This indicates that the region represented by peptide 8 indeed contains essential determinants that are strictly required for recognition of PratA. It is intriguing that, based on available structural data of crystallized PSII, this D1 region forms an α-helical structure (4Loll B. Kern J. Saenger W. Zouni A. Biesiadka J. Nature. 2005; 438: 1040-1044Crossref PubMed Scopus (1616) Google Scholar). To substantiate this hypothesis, we replaced the threonine at position 316 with a glycine, because alignments of D1 sequences from various organisms revealed that Thr-316 is the only highly conserved amino acid at the left end (Ile-Gly-Thr) of the helix region. Yeast two-hybrid analysis indeed revealed that the T316G mutation is sufficient to prevent PratA binding completely (Fig. 2C). Transcriptional control of Runx2 gene expression through two alternative promoters (P1 and P2) is critical for the execution of its function as an osteogenic cell fate determining factor. In all vertebrates examined to date, the bone related P1 promoter contains a purine-rich region (-303 to -128 bp in the rat) that separates two regulatory domains. The length of this region differs dramatically between species even within the same order. Using deletion analysis, we show that part of this purine-rich region (-200 to -128) containing a duplicated element (Y-repeat) positively regulates Runx2 P1 transcription. Electrophoretic mobility assays and chromatin immunoprecipitations reveal that Y-repeat binds at least two different classes of transcription factors related to GC box binding proteins (e.g. SP1 and SP7/Osterix) and ETS-like factors (e.g. ETS1 and ELK1). Forced expression of SP1 increases Runx2 P1 promoter activity through the Y-repeats, and small interfering RNA depletion of SP1 decreases Runx2 expression. Similarly, exogenous expression of wild type ELK1, but not a defective mutant that cannot be phosphorylated, enhances Runx2 gene expression. SP1 is most abundant in proliferating cells, and ELK1 is most abundant in postconfluent cells; during MC3T3-E1 osteoblast differentiation, both proteins are transiently co-expressed when Runx2 expression is enhanced. Taken together, our data suggest that basal Runx2 gene transcription is regulated by dynamic interactions between SP1 and ETS-like factors during progression of osteogenesis.

Background In the present study, synchrotron small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) and Cryo-TEM were used to characterize the temperature-induced structural transitions of monoelaidin (ME) aqueous dispersion in the presence of the polymeric stabilizer F127. We prove that the direct transition from vesicles to cubosomes by heating this dispersion is possible. The obtained results were compared with the fully hydrated bulk ME phase. Methodology/Principal Findings Our results indicate the formation of ME dispersion, which is less stable than that based on the congener monoolein (MO). In addition, the temperature-dependence behavior significantly differs from the fully hydrated bulk phase. SAXS findings indicate a direct Lα-V2 internal transition in the dispersion. While the transition temperature is conserved in the dispersion, the formed cubosomes with internal Im3m symmetry clearly contain more water and this ordered interior is retained over a wider temperature range as compared to its fully hydrated bulk system. At 25°C, Cryo-TEM observations reveal the formation of most likely closely packed onion-like vesicles. Above the lamellar to non-lamellar phase transition at 65°C, flattened cubosomes with an internal nanostructure are observed. However, they have only arbitrary shapes and thus, their morphology is significantly different from that of the well-shaped analogous MO cubosome and hexosome particles. Conclusions/Significance Our study reveals a direct liposomes-cubosomes transition in ME dispersion. The obtained results suggest that the polymeric stabilizer F127 especially plays a significant role in the membrane fusion processes. F127 incorporates in considerable amount into the internal nanostructure and leads to the formation of a highly swollen Im3m phase.

ASAP1 is an Arf GTPase-activating protein (GAP) that functions on membrane surfaces to catalyze the hydrolysis of GTP bound to Arf. ASAP1 contains a tandem of BAR, pleckstrin homology (PH), and Arf GAP domains and contributes to the formation of invadopodia and podosomes. The PH domain interacts with the catalytic domain influencing both the catalytic and Michaelis constants. Tandem BAR-PH domains have been found to fold into a functional unit. The results of sedimentation velocity studies were consistent with predictions from homology models in which the BAR and PH domains of ASAP1 fold together. We set out to test the hypothesis that the BAR domain of ASAP1 affects GAP activity by interacting with the PH and/or Arf GAP domains. Recombinant proteins composed of the BAR, PH, Arf GAP, and Ankyrin repeat domains (called BAR-PZA) and the PH, Arf GAP, and Ankyrin repeat domains (PZA) were compared. Catalytic power for the two proteins was determined using large unilamellar vesicles as a reaction surface. The catalytic power of PZA was greater than that of BAR-PZA. The effect of the BAR domain was dependent on the N-terminal loop of the BAR domain and was not the consequence of differential membrane association or changes in large unilamellar vesicle curvature. The Km for BAR-PZA was greater and the kcat was smaller than for PZA determined by saturation kinetics. Analysis of single turnover kinetics revealed a transition state intermediate that was affected by the BAR domain. ASAP1 is an Arf GTPase-activating protein (GAP) that functions on membrane surfaces to catalyze the hydrolysis of GTP bound to Arf. ASAP1 contains a tandem of BAR, pleckstrin homology (PH), and Arf GAP domains and contributes to the formation of invadopodia and podosomes. The PH domain interacts with the catalytic domain influencing both the catalytic and Michaelis constants. Tandem BAR-PH domains have been found to fold into a functional unit. The results of sedimentation velocity studies were consistent with predictions from homology models in which the BAR and PH domains of ASAP1 fold together. We set out to test the hypothesis that the BAR domain of ASAP1 affects GAP activity by interacting with the PH and/or Arf GAP domains. Recombinant proteins composed of the BAR, PH, Arf GAP, and Ankyrin repeat domains (called BAR-PZA) and the PH, Arf GAP, and Ankyrin repeat domains (PZA) were compared. Catalytic power for the two proteins was determined using large unilamellar vesicles as a reaction surface. The catalytic power of PZA was greater than that of BAR-PZA. The effect of the BAR domain was dependent on the N-terminal loop of the BAR domain and was not the consequence of differential membrane association or changes in large unilamellar vesicle curvature. The Km for BAR-PZA was greater and the kcat was smaller than for PZA determined by saturation kinetics. Analysis of single turnover kinetics revealed a transition state intermediate that was affected by the BAR domain. We conclude that BAR domains can affect enzymatic activity through intraprotein interactions. We recently established the critical role of the PTEN/MAGI-1b signalosome in stabilization of cell-cell contacts and suppression of invasiveness. The PTEN tumor suppressor is recruited to E-cadherin junctional complexes through the binding to the second PDZ domain of the MAGI-1b scaffolding molecule, whereas beta-catenin interacts with the fifth PDZ domain. To identify additional effectors of this signalosome, we used yeast 2-hybrid screening. Among the clones identified, we focused on TRIP6, which belongs to the zyxin family of proteins. We demonstrated that TRIP6 interacted directly with MAGI-1b by binding to its fifth PDZ domain. Ectopic expression of TRIP6 induced invasiveness in the epithelial MDCK and MDCKts-src cells in a PI3-kinase- and a NF-kappaB-dependent manner and impaired cell-cell aggregation at least in part by uncoupling adherens junctional complexes from the cytoskeleton. The TRIP6Stop473 mutant, which lacks the PDZ binding motif, was still able to increase NF-kappaB and Akt activities but did not promote invasiveness or interfere with cell-cell aggregation. Intracellular delivery of competing peptides corresponding to TRIP6 or beta-catenin C terminus restored invasive properties in MDCKts-src TRIP6Stop473 cells, highlighting the requirement of PDZ scaffolds in junctional complexes activity. TRIP6 overexpression in colon tumors suggest its critical role in cancer progression.

The TIM23 complex is the major translocase of the mitochondrial inner membrane responsible for the import of essentially all matrix proteins and a number of inner membrane proteins. Tim23 and Tim50, two essential proteins of the complex, expose conserved domains into the intermembrane space that interact with each other. Here, we describe in vitro reconstitution of this interaction using recombinantly expressed and purified intermembrane space domains of Tim50 and Tim23. We established two independent methods, chemical cross-linking and surface plasmon resonance, to track their interaction. In addition, we identified mutations in Tim23 that abolish its interaction with Tim50 in vitro. These mutations also destabilized the interaction between the two proteins in vivo, leading to defective import of preproteins via the TIM23 complex and to cell death at higher temperatures. This is the first study to describe the reconstitution of the Tim50-Tim23 interaction in vitro and to identify specific residues of Tim23 that are vital for the interaction with Tim50. Volume can provide informative structural descriptions of macromolecules such as proteins in solution because a final volumetric outcome accompanies the exquisite equipoise of packing effects between residues, and residues and waters inside and outside proteins. Here we performed systematic investigations on the volumetric nature of the amyloidogenic conformations of β2-microglobulin (β2-m) and its amyloidogenic core peptide, K3, using a high precision densitometer. The transition from the acid-denatured β2-m to the mature amyloid fibrils was accompanied by a positive change in the partial specific volume, which was larger than that observed for the transition from the acid-denatured β2-m to the native structure. The data imply that the mature amyloid fibrils are more voluminous than the native structure because of a sparse packing density of side chains. In contrast, the formation of the mature amyloid-like fibrils of the K3 from the random coil was followed by a considerable decrease in the partial specific volume, suggesting a highly compact core structure. Interestingly, the immature amyloid-like fibrils of β2-m exhibited a volume intermediate between those of the mature fibrils of β2-m and K3, because of the core structure at their center and the relatively noncompact region around the core with much hydration. These volumetric differences would result from the nature of main-chain-dominated fibrillogenesis. We suggest comprehensive models for these three types of fibrils illustrating packing and hydrational states. However, it has been recognized that a misfolding-induced ordered aggregate, known as an amyloid, is an alternative fold that might be in the global minimum of free energy (1Jahn T.R. Radford S.E. Arch. Biochem. Biophys.. 2008; 469: 100-117Google Scholar). Intriguingly, various nonamyloidogenic polypeptides can also assemble into fibrillar structures, implying that fibrillation is a generic property of polypeptides (2Dobson C.M. Nature.. 2003; 426: 884-890Google Scholar). This raises the possibility that although the native structure depends on interactions among side chains of amino acid residues, i.e. a side-chain-dominated structure, the amyloidogenic structure does not depend on interactions of side chains, i.e. a main-chain-dominated structure. To our surprise, the extent of the partial volumetric changes upon the formation of the mature fibrils and immature fibrils of β2-m, and the mature fibrils of K3, differed. Here we report the partial volume and states of these three fibrillar conformations in light of the main-chain-dominated fibrillation and the core structure of fibrils with polymorphism. Preparation and Characterization of the Samples—Recombinant human β2-m was expressed and purified using the Escherichia coli expression system as described (15Kihara M. Chatani E. Iwata K. Yamamoto K. Matsuura T. Nakagawa A. Naiki H. Goto Y. J. Biol. Chem.. 2006; 281: 31061-31069Google Scholar). For CD and measurements of density, β2-m was dissolved in 6 mm HCl (pH 2.3) and 38 mm NaCl or 50 mm citrate buffer (pH 2.5) in the presence and absence of 5.7 m Gdn-HCl and, in turn, K3 in solution of 6 mm HCl and 38 mm NaCl. Mature β2-m fibrils of 1.2 mg·ml-1 were elongated in a 6 mm HCl solution (pH 2.3) containing 38 mm NaCl in the presence of 5 μg·ml-1 of seeds, ultrasonicated fibrils, at 37 °C for ∼14 h. The short mature fibrils were prepared by ultrasonicating the fresh mature fibrils 100 times on ice using a Microson sonicator (Misonix, Farmingdale, NY) at intensity level 2 and with 20 1-s pulses. Chem.. 2002; 277: 21554-21560Google Scholar) in a reaction mixture containing 0.6 mg·ml-1 of recombinant β2-m, 50 mm citrate buffer (pH 2.5), and 200 mm NaCl. The reaction solution was incubated at 37 °C for ∼90 h. Mature fibrils of K3 were seed-dependently polymerized by K3 monomer in the solution containing 6 mm HCl, 7 mm NaCl, and 0.00091% 2,2,2-trifluoroethanol. Sedimentation Velocity (SV) with Analytical Ultracentrifugation (AUC)—SV measurements were performed on the mature and immature fibrils of β2-m and the mature fibrils of K3 at 5 °C using a Beckman-Coulter Optima XL-1 analytical ultracentrifuge (Fullerton, CA) equipped with an An-60 rotor and two- or six-channel charcoal-filled Epon cells. After pre-centrifugation at 700 × g for 5 min, the rotor speed was increased to 17,400–31,000 × g. The sedimentation curves were recorded using absorbance data at 280 nm at intervals of 10–20 min. All conditions for SV were identical to those for polymerization reactions except temperature. Each measurement was conducted with a radial increment of 0.003 cm in a continuous scanning mode. High Precision Density Measurements—All measurements of density were made using a vibrating tube density meter (DMA5000, Anton Paar, Austria) with a precision of 1 × 10-6 g·ml-1, and the polypeptide concentration was between 0.25 and 4 mg·ml-1. To prevent condensation in measuring density at 5 °C, a U-shaped densitometric cell was thoroughly dried with the use of a dry air pump, and ambient relative air humidity and temperature were kept under 30% and 25 °C, respectively. Hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) is a key enzyme in the mobilization of fatty acids from stored triacylglycerols. Its activity is regulated by reversible protein phosphorylation. In rat HSL Ser563, Ser659 and Ser660 have been shown to be phosphorylated by protein kinase A (PKA) in vitro as well as in vivo.In this study we employed site-directed mutagenesis, in vitro phosphorylation and mass spectrometry to show that in vitro phosphorylation of human HSL by PKA occurs primarily on Ser649 and Ser650 (Ser659 and Ser660 in rat HSL). The wild type enzyme and four mutants were expressed in C-terminally His-tagged form in Sf9 insect cells and purified to homogeneity. HSL variants in which Ser552 and/or Ser554 were mutated to Ala or Glu retained both lipolytic and non-lipolytic activity and were phosphorylated by PKA and activated to a similar extent as the wild type enzyme. (32)P-labeling studies revealed that the bulk of the phosphorylation was on the Ser649/Ser650 site, with only a minor phosphorylation of Ser552 and Ser554. MS/MS analysis demonstrated that the peptide containing Ser649 and Ser650 was primarily phosphorylated on Ser650. The mutant lacking all four serines had severely reduced lipolytic activity, but a lesser reduction in non-lipolytic activity, had S(0.5) values for p-nitrophenol butyrate and triolein comparable to those of wild type HSL and was not phosphorylated by PKA. PKA phosphorylation of the wild type enzyme resulted in an increase in both the maximum turnover and S(0,5) using the TO substrate.Our results demonstrate that PKA activates human HSL against lipid substrates in vitro primarily through phosphorylation of Ser649 and Ser650. In addition the results suggest that Ser649 and Ser650 are located in the vicinity of a lipid binding region and that PKA phosphorylation controls the accessibility of this region.

It has been suggested previously (AbdAlla, S., Lother, H., and Quitterer, U. (2000) Nature 407, 94-98) that the angiotensin II type 1 receptor (AT1R) and the bradykinin B2 receptor (B2R) form constitutive heterodimers. Furthermore they demonstrate that AT1R signaling significantly increases in the presence of the B2R. These findings suggest that heterodimerization and potentiation of AT1R signaling is a universal phenomenon that occurs as a natural consequence of simultaneous expression of the two receptors. Hence this potential interaction is of great pharmacological and biological interest that adds an additional layer of complexity to the understanding of the cross-talk between the renin-angiotensin and kallikrein-kinin systems. Given the remarkable significance of this finding, scientists from four independent research groups have set out to reproduce and further examine the potential AT1R/B2R interaction. We have investigated functional potentiation by the B2R of AT1R signaling in three different cell lines using multiple assays including phosphoinositide hydrolysis, ERK activation, β-arrestin recruitment, and receptor selection and amplification technology, and we have examined dimerization using bioluminescence resonance energy transfer and regulated secretion/aggregation technology. However, although both the AT1Rs and B2Rs were functional in our systems and the systems were fine tuned to detect small changes in receptor function, we failed to detect any functional modulation by or physical interaction between the two receptor proteins. In contrast to the previous observations, our data collectively suggest that AT1R/B2R heterodimerization does not occur as a natural consequence of their simultaneous expression in the same cell nor does the B2R influence the AT1R signaling. The concept of 7TM receptor heterodimerization is of emerging importance, and it will be crucial to address general questions with respect to experimental pitfalls, specificity, generality, and biological significance of a given heterodimeric interaction. Scientists from four independent groups set out to study the putative AT1R/B2R heterodimerization in detail. Surprisingly although both the AT1Rs and the B2Rs were functional in our studies, we were not able to establish any functional potentiation or physical interaction between the two receptors. Despite careful experimental fine tuning, our data do not support the concept of an AT1R/B2R heterodimer occurring as a natural consequence of simultaneous AT1R and B2R expression in the same cell. The relationship between contextual information and object perception has received considerable attention in neuroimaging studies. In the work reported here, we used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to investigate the relationship between aesthetic judgment and images of objects in their normal contextual setting versus images of objects in abnormal contextual settings and the underlying brain activity. When object-context relationships are violated changes in visual perception and aesthetic judgment emerges that exposes the contribution of vision to interpretations shaped by previous experience. We found that effects of context on aesthetic judgment modulates different memory sub-systems, while aesthetic judgment regardless of context recruit medial and lateral aspects of the orbitofrontal cortex, consistent with previous findings. Visual cortical areas traditionally associated with the processing of visual features are recruited in normal contexts, irrespective of aesthetic ratings, while prefrontal areas are significantly more engaged when objects are viewed in unaccustomed settings.

A great deal of sub-cellular organelle positioning, and essentially all minus-ended organelle transport, depends on cytoplasmic dynein, but how dynein's function is regulated is not well understood. BicD is established to play a critical role in mediating dynein function-loss of BicD results in improperly localized nuclei, mRNA particles, and a dispersed Golgi apparatus-however exactly what BicD's role is remains unknown. Nonetheless, it is widely believed that BicD may act to tether dynein to cargos. Here we use a combination of biophysical and biochemical studies to investigate BicD's role in lipid droplet transport during Drosophila embryogenesis.Functional loss of BicD impairs the embryo's ability to control the net direction of droplet transport; the developmentally controlled reversal in transport is eliminated. We find that minimal BicD expression (near-BicD(null)) decreases the average run length of both plus and minus end directed microtubule (MT) based transport. A point mutation affecting the BicD N-terminus has very similar effects on transport during cellularization (phase II), but in phase III (gastrulation) motion actually appears better than in the wild-type.In contrast to a simple static tethering model of BicD function, or a role only in initial dynein recruitment to the cargo, our data uncovers a new dynamic role for BicD in actively regulating transport. Lipid droplets move bi-directionally, and our investigations demonstrate that BicD plays a critical-and temporally changing-role in balancing the relative contributions of plus-end and minus-end motors to control the net direction of transport. Our results suggest that while BicD might contribute to recruitment of dynein to the cargo it is not absolutely required for such dynein localization, and it clearly contributes to regulation, helping activation/inactivation of the motors.

The regulation of gene expression through alternative pre-mRNA splicing is common in metazoans and is often controlled by intracellular signaling pathways that are important in cell physiology. We have shown that the alternative splicing of a number of genes is controlled by membrane depolarization and Ca2+/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase IV (CaMKIV) through CaMKIV-responsive RNA elements (CaRRE1 and CaRRE2); however, the trans-acting factors remain unknown. Here we show that the heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein (hnRNP) L is a CaRRE1 binding factor in nuclear extracts. An hnRNP L high affinity CA (cytidine-adenosine) repeat element is sufficient to mediate CaMKIV and hnRNP L repression of splicing in a location (3′-splice site proximity)-dependent way. Depletion of hnRNP L by RNA interference followed by rescue with coexpressed exogenous hnRNP L demonstrates that hnRNP L mediates the CaMKIV-regulated splicing through CA repeats in heterologous contexts. Depletion of hnRNP L also led to increased inclusion of the stress axis-regulated exon and a CA repeat-harboring exon under depolarization or with activated CaMKIV. Moreover, hnRNP L binding to CaRRE1 was increased by CaMKIV and, conversely, was reduced by pretreatments with protein phosphatases. Therefore, hnRNP L is an essential component of CaMKIV-regulated alternative splicing through CA repeats, with its phosphorylation likely playing a critical role. For the HEK293T cells in 24-well plates, 0.1 μg of splicing reporter minigene plasmid and 0.3 μg of another plasmid including CaMKIV-dCT (IV), CaMKIV-dCTK75E (IVm), or hnRNP L-FLAG were used. In brief, 2 × 107 HEK293T cells were transfected with 5 μg of pHCMVG, 12.5 μg of pCMVΔR8.2DVPR, and 12.5 μg of the lentiviral plasmids. Culture supernatant was collected on days 2 and 3 post-transfection, pooled, and filtered through a 0.22-μm filter. Viral supernatant was further concentrated 100 times by ultracentrifugation at 17,000 rpm for 90 min. Titers of the concentrated virus were determined by enhanced green fluorescent protein expression in transduced HEK293T cells. For transduction, HEK293T cells were plated at a density of 6 × 104 cells per well in a 24-well plate (Falcon) on day 1. On day 2, 25 μl of lentivirus stock (titer ∼1 × 108 units) was mixed with 225 μl of Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (Invitrogen) then with 2.0 μl of Polybrene (1 μg/μl), gently vortexed, allowed to sit at room temperature for 5 min, incubated at 37 °C for 10 min, and then pipetted onto the cells. The cells were then incubated with the virus supernatant at 37 °C, 5% CO2 for 2.5–3.0 h before fresh media were supplied. On day 3 the cells were infected again as on day 2 and transferred into a 6-well plate. On day 5, the cells were cotransfected with 0.5 μg of splicing reporter minigene plasmids and 1.5 μg of CaMKIV-dCT or CaMKIV-dCTK75E plasmid. Clostridium perfringens produces numerous toxins, which are responsible for severe diseases in man and animals. Delta toxin is one of the three hemolysins released by a number of C. perfringens type C and possibly type B strains. Delta toxin was characterized to be cytotoxic for cells expressing the ganglioside G(M2) in their membrane. Here we report the genetic characterization of Delta toxin and its pore forming activity in lipid bilayers. Delta toxin consists of 318 amino acids, its 28 N-terminal amino acids corresponding to a signal peptide. The secreted Delta toxin (290 amino acids; 32619 Da) is a basic protein (pI 9.1) which shows a significant homology with C. perfringens Beta toxin (43% identity), with C. perfringens NetB (40% identity) and, to a lesser extent, with Staphylococcus aureus alpha toxin and leukotoxins. Recombinant Delta toxin showed a preference for binding to G(M2), in contrast to Beta toxin, which did not bind to gangliosides. It is hemolytic for sheep red blood cells and cytotoxic for HeLa cells. In artificial diphytanoyl phosphatidylcholine membranes, Delta and Beta toxin formed channels. Conductance of the channels formed by Delta toxin, with a value of about 100 pS to more than 1 nS in 1 M KCl and a membrane potential of 20 mV, was higher than those formed by Beta toxin and their distribution was broader. The results of zero-current membrane potential measurements and single channel experiments suggest that Delta toxin forms slightly anion-selective channels, whereas the Beta toxin channels showed a preference for cations under the same conditions. C. perfringens Delta toxin shows a significant sequence homolgy with C. perfringens Beta and NetB toxins, as well as with S. aureus alpha hemolysin and leukotoxins, but exhibits different channel properties in lipid bilayers. In contrast to Beta toxin, Delta toxin recognizes G(M2) as receptor and forms anion-selective channels.

[NiFe] hydrogenases catalyze the reversible conversion of H2 into protons and electrons. The reaction takes place at the active site, which is composed of a nickel and an iron atom and three diatomic ligands, two cyanides and one carbon monoxide, bound to the iron. The NiFe(CN-)2CO cofactor is synthesized by an intricate posttranslational maturation process, which is mediated by a set of six conserved Hyp proteins. Depending on the cellular location and the physiological function, additional auxiliary proteins are involved in hydrogenase biosynthesis. Here we present evidence that the auxiliary proteins HoxL and HoxV assist in assembly of the Fe(CN-)2CO moiety. This unit was identified as a cofactor intermediate of the oxygen-tolerant membrane-bound [NiFe] hydrogenase (MBH) in the β-proteobacterium Ralstonia eutropha H16. Both HoxL and HoxV proved to be essential for H2-oxidizing activity and MBH-driven growth on H2. Copurification studies revealed that HoxL and HoxV directly interact with the hydrogenase apoprotein. HoxV forms complexes with HoxL and HypC, a HoxL paralogue that is essential for cofactor assembly. These observations suggest that HoxL acts as a specific chaperone assisting the transfer of the Fe(CN-)2CO cofactor intermediate from the Hyp machinery to the MBH. This shuttle also involves the scaffold protein HoxV. Indeed, infrared spectroscopy and metal analysis identified for the first time a non-redox-active Fe(CN-)2CO intermediate coordinated to HoxV. Media and Growth Conditions—Strains of Re were grown in Luria broth medium containing 0.25% (w/v) sodium chloride (LSLB) or in mineral salts medium (38Schlegel H.G. Kaltwasser H. Gottschalk G. Arch. Mikrobiol.. 1961; 38: 209-222Google Scholar). Sucrose-resistant segregants of sacB-harboring strains were selected on LSLB plates containing 15% (w/v) sucrose (37Lenz O. Schwartz E. Dernedde J. Eitinger M. Friedrich B. J. Bacteriol.. 1994; 176: 4385-4393Google Scholar). Strains of E. coli were grown in Luria broth medium (39Miller J.H. Experiments in Molecular Genetics. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1972Google Scholar). Solid media contained 1.5% (w/v) agar. Antibiotics for Re were used at the following concentrations: kanamycin, 350 μgml-1; tetracycline, 15 μgml-1. Antibiotics for E. coli were used at the following concentrations: kanamycin, 25 μgml-1; tetracycline, 15 μgml-1; ampicillin, 100 μgml-1. When cultivated on a small scale (0.1–1-liter culture volume), cells were grown under hydrogenase-derepressing conditions in mineral salts medium containing 0.2% fructose and 0.2% glycerol at continuous shaking at 120 rpm (40Schwartz E. Gerischer U. Friedrich B. J. Bacteriol.. 1998; 180: 3197-3204Google Scholar). For large-scale purifications, cells were grown in a fermenter (Biostat MD; Braun) at continuous stirring at 400 rpm. Cells were harvested (centrifugation at 5000 × g at 4 °C for 20 min) after 48 h of cultivation at 30 °C at an A436 of about 10. Preparation of Membrane Fraction and Soluble Extract—The cell pellets resulting from 100-ml cultures were resuspended in 2 ml of K-PO4 buffer (50 mM, K2HPO4/KH2PO4, pH 7.0), DNase I was added (20 μg). The cells were disrupted using a French pressure cell (SLM Aminco) and centrifuged (4000 × g, 4 °C, 20 min). The supernatant was then ultracentrifuged at 100,000 × g at 4 °C for 45 min to separate the membrane fraction from soluble extract. The membrane fraction was homogenized in an appropriate volume of 50 mm K-PO4 buffer (pH 7.0), ultracentrifuged again at 100,000 × g at 4 °C for 30 min, and homogenized in 200 μl50 mm K-PO4 buffer (pH 7.0). Protein Purification—For purification of StrepTag II-tagged proteins, the cells were resuspended in 1 ml of 100 mm Tris/HCl buffer (pH 8.0), 150 mm NaCl (washing buffer) per 1 g of cell material, and protease inhibitor mixture (Complete EDTA-free protease inhibitor mixture; Roche Applied Science) was added. The cells were disrupted using a French pressure cell (SLM Aminco), and the crude extract was ultracentrifuged (100,000 × g, 4 °C, 45 min). The supernatant was loaded on StrepTactin Superflow columns (2.5-ml columns, 1-ml bed volume; MoBiTec) equilibrated with washing buffer (maximum 25 ml of solubilized membrane extract per column). In the case of large scale preparations (60 g of cell material), the StrepTactin matrix (4 ml) was added to the soluble extract. After stirring for 1 h on ice, the suspension was transferred to two 10-ml columns (MoBiTec). The columns were washed with 12 column volumes of washing buffer and eluted with elution buffer (washing buffer, 5 mm desthiobiotin). The protein-containing fractions were pooled and concentrated using a centrifugal filter device (Amicon Ultra-15 (PL-10 or PL-30); Millipore). For Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) analysis, the protein solution was further concentrated using Amicon Microcon (YM-30) (Millipore). For metal determination of HoxV, the eluate after the StrepTactin column was further purified using gel filtration (HiLoad 16/60 Superdex 200 preparation grade column; Amersham Biosciences). HoxV-containing fractions were pooled and concentrated using Amicon Ultra-15 (PL-30) and Microcon (YM-30). The protein concentration was determined by the Bradford method (41Bradford M.M. Anal. Biochem.. 1976; 72: 248-254Google Scholar) using bovine serum albumin as a standard. The purity of the samples was examined by SDS-PAGE (42Laemmli U.K. Nature.. 1970; 227: 680-685Google Scholar). Enzyme Assays—Hydrogenase activity in the membrane fraction was measured as described previously (21Schink B. Schlegel H.G. Biochim. Biophys. Acta.. 1979; 567: 315-324Google Scholar) in 50 mm K-PO4 buffer at pH 7.0. Methylene blue was used as an artificial electron acceptor, and its absorption at 570 nm was measured spectrophotometrically. Western Immunoblot Analysis—Proteins were resolved using denaturing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (42Laemmli U.K. Nature.. 1970; 227: 680-685Google Scholar). Western immunoblot analysis was performed according to a standard protocol (43Towbin H. Staehelin T. Gordon J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A.. 1979; 76: 4350-4354Google Scholar). For immunological detection of hydrogenase-related proteins, antisera were applied in the following dilutions: anti-HoxG serum (1:10,000), anti-HypC serum (1:500 dilution), and anti-HypD serum (1:500 dilution). Antibodies directed against the MBH accessory proteins HoxL and HoxV were produced by rabbit immunization with the respective proteins, purified under denaturing conditions. Infrared and EPR Spectroscopy—Infrared spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer equipped with a liquid nitrogen-cooled MCT detector at a spectral resolution of 2 cm-1. The sample compartment was purged with dried air, and the sample (0.66–1.83 mm protein) was held in a temperature-controlled (10 °C) gas-tight liquid cell (volume ∼7 μl, path length = 50 μm) with CaF2 windows. Spectra were baseline-corrected by using a spline function implemented within OPUS 4.2 software supplied by Bruker. The spectra shown in this work were normalized with respect to the protein concentration. Attempts to reduce the samples were carried out with excess dithionite under anaerobic conditions. Human Dicer is an integral component of the RNA interference pathway. Dicer processes premicro-RNA and double-strand RNA to, respectively, mature micro-RNA and short interfering RNA (siRNA) and transfers the processed products to the RNA-induced silencing complex. To better understand the factors that are important for the binding, translocation, and selective recognition of the siRNA strands, we determined the binding affinities of human Dicer for processed products (siRNA) and short single-strand RNAs (ssRNA). siRNAs and ssRNAs competitively inhibited human Dicer activity, suggesting that they are interacting with the active site of the enzyme. The dissociation constants (Kd) for unmodified siRNAs were 5-11-fold weaker compared with a 27-nucleotide double-strand RNA substrate. Chemically modified siRNAs exhibited binding affinities for Dicer comparable with the substrate. 3′-Dinucleotide overhangs in the siRNA affected the binding affinity of human Dicer for the siRNA and biased strand loading into RNA-induced silencing complex. The Kd values for the ssRNAs ranged from 3- to 40-fold weaker than the Kd for the substrate. Sequence composition of the 3′-terminal nucleotides of the ssRNAs exhibited the greatest effect on Dicer binding. Dicer cleaved substrates containing short siRNA-like double-strand regions and extended 3′ or 5′ ssRNA overhangs in the adjacent ssRNA regions. Remarkably, cleavage sites were observed consistent with the enzyme entering the substrate from the extended 3′ ssRNA terminus. These data suggest that the siRNAs and ssRNAs interact predominantly with the PAZ domain of the enzyme. Finally, the tightest binding siRNAs were also more potent inhibitors of gene expression. Filipowicz W. EMBO J.. 2002; 21: 5875-5885Google Scholar). To better understand the interaction between human Dicer and its siRNA cleavage products as well as the properties important for the translocation of the siRNA from Dicer to RISC, we determined the binding affinities of human Dicer for substrate and various native and chemically modified siRNAs and short single-strand RNAs (ssRNA). Based on the observed binding interactions between the enzyme and the siRNAs and ssRNAs, substrates containing short siRNA-like double-strand regions and extended 3′ or 5′ single-strand RNA regions were prepared, and the Dicer cleavage activities were determined. Finally, we compared the gene silencing activities of various modified and unmodified siRNAs in cultured cells with the binding affinities of human Dicer for the siRNAs.
